statement.tex: \text{Find the integral of the function}\\ \sin x \cdot \sin 2 x \cdot \sin 3 x \,

step.context: \text{Are the following calculations and analysis correct?}
step.tex:
\text{Using trignometric identity,}\\
\begin{align}
\sin A \sin B &= \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos (A-B) - \cos (A+B)] \\ \implies \sin 2x \sin 3x &= \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos x - \cos 5 x] \\ \end{align}\\
\text{So, } \sin x \cdot \sin 2x \cdot \sin 3 x \\ \qquad \qquad = \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin x \cos x - \sin x \cos 5 x] \\ \text{Using, }\sin A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}\left[ cos(A-B) - cos(A+B) \right] \\ \qquad \qquad = \dfrac{1}{4} [ \sin 2 x + \sin 0 - \sin 6x +sin 4x] \\
\therefore \int \sin x \cdot \sin 2 x \cdot \sin 3 x \, dx \\ \qquad \qquad = \int \dfrac{1}{4} [ \sin 2 x - \sin 6x +sin 4x] dx

step.context: \text{Is the following evaluation of the integral}\\ \int \dfrac{1}{4} [ \sin 2 x - \sin 6x +sin 4x] dx \quad \text{correct}?
step.tex:
\int \dfrac{1}{4} [ \sin 2 x - \sin 6x +sin 4x] dx \\ = \dfrac{1}{4}\int \sin (2 x) dx - \dfrac{1}{4}\int \sin (6 x) dx + \dfrac{1}{4} \int sin(4 x) dx \\
= \dfrac {1} {4}\left[ \dfrac{- 1}{2} {\cos 2 x} + \dfrac{1}{6}{\cos6 x} - \dfrac{1}{4}{\cos 4x} \right]+ C

= \dfrac {1} {4}\left[ \dfrac{ 1}{2} {\cos 2 x} - \dfrac{1}{6}{\cos6 x} + \dfrac{1}{4}{\cos 4x} \right]+ C
